I'm not a basketball fan or a sports fan of any kind, but Mr. Goodson's story stuck with me.
When I heard this morning that Kansas had won the NCAA tournament, I remembered his math team's prediction.
If anyone ever deserved an A-plus from their professor, I would say that these students do.
Well, many of you sent comments about my interview with Gene Weingarten of the Washington Post Magazine.
He won a Pulitzer Prize yesterday for his story about placing a world class violinist inside a Washington, D.C., Metro Station.
Joshua Bell played during the morning rush hour, but only one person recognized him.
Seth Barken(ph) knows how that feels.
He works as a cocktail pianist in Las Vegas.
He writes, I was not at all surprised to hear the disheartening results of The Washington Post subway experiment.
Barken goes on, although I make absolutely no claim to be on the same level as Mr. Bell, I have had my moments in front of uncaring audiences.
The fact is that we live in the world where music is so ubiquitous that people no longer care about the magic of live performance.
Welcome to my world and remember to always tip; it makes our nights.
We're also accepting tips - ideas, not gratuities.
Just go to npr.org/contact.

One of President Musharraf's senior legal advisers is in Washington this week, defending the need for a state of emergency.
Ahmed Raza Kasuri is also a senior advocate of the supreme court of Pakistan and one of the authors of Pakistan's constitution written in 1973.
Despite the calls for mass street protests from opposition leaders, Kasuri says the protest will end in a few days time.
He says they will not gain widespread popular support.
Kasuri stopped by our studios today.
He acknowledged the suspension of Pakistan's constitution and the dismissal of the Supreme Court was an extreme step, but he says it was necessary for the good of the country.
The first responsibility of the state government, the government of Pakistani, to see that Pakistan stays as a stable and integrated Pakistan.
If Pakistan is there, there'll be scores of election, there'll be rule of law, the courts will also be there to exercise their judicial activism.
But presently, the (unintelligible) of the country are refloating, and that is the responsibility of government of Pakistan, to see that the state have to remain intact.
But here in Studio 2A here in Washington, D.C., you're talking about a country that seems to be moving toward some sort of stability, that things will move toward much more of an even keel.
But everything that we see - the reporting out of Pakistan today, the pictures of the police clashing once again with the lawyers - seems to say otherwise.
And again, with Benazir Bhutto who's associated with the largest political party in the country calling for mass street protests, it doesn't seem like the country is heading toward more stability.
It seems like you're speeding toward more chaos.
No, these are all media hype, you know.
I mean, you withdraw the media and you will find nothing on the ground.
This is a media hype.
This is the same media created a hype that there'll be no election of the president and he was elected.

Now you are an advocate, an adviser and a good friend of President Musharraf, so, are you at all concerned about his authority and his credibility, how he can stand and justify his crackdown on one hand against militants when at the same time he is cracking down on any kind of political dissidents in his country - throwing lawyers and human rights workers in jail, placing them under house arrest, sanctioning, in some cases, there are beatings at the hands of police.
You see, the position is that if the - somebody will take law into the hand.
There's Section 144 which means that more than five people can't come on the streets.
I mean, the idea is to maintain the stability and the law and order.
Now, there's rule of law but there's also respect, which authority really relies on - holding onto the respect of the people.
And are you concerned that this will undermine his authority in the long run?
You know, he is very, very, very, very strong.
He has been elected for second term.
Election will take place.
He's got a very powerful party.
Kindly see, you have in your country a long history of democratic tradition and values, after 9/11, what have you done?
See, you have also introduced emergency.
You can pick up anybody - detentions, where the court's part is totally stripped off.
Well, these are the some of the measures that you have to adopt in order to maintain stability of the country, and prime consolation is integrity and stability of the country.
I mean, there are a lot of fingers raised on you when you talk of the rule of law and, what you call it, due process of law.
There are so many fingers on you that you are running a Guantanamo Bay where the Supreme Court of United States does not have exists.
If we had become unpopular, we have become unpopular, following your agenda against terrorism.
And if today we say that we have nothing to do with terrorism, today there will be people on the streets of Pakistan raising slogan for the government with long live, Musharraf city.
If you will dictate us and threaten us the discontinuation of your aid, that's not good.
That's being very unfair.
And we are trying to contain the menace of terrorism in that part of the world.
Yeah, exactly.

How does how do these scientists find these topics?
The secret life - say it one more time: the secret life of the red-eyed tree frog.
That's right.
And you've probably seen a picture.
Most people have probably seen a picture of one of these guys.
They're the really bright green frogs.
They've got blue on their sides and...
Yeah, yeah.
...as the name suggests, those really beet-red eyes.
And...
So they're not the rare things you never going to see.
These are not (unintelligible).
I mean, they're like National Geographic's favorites, you know?
(Soundbite of laughter)
They're really pretty and really cute in the light of day.
But what's their secret?
That's right.
So, Michael Caldwell went to Panama, and he had heard that these tree frogs have this mysterious behavior, where they shake.
There is this old paper, 40 years ago, some scientists had written about this.
And he studies them, and he had never seen this.
So he's looking at them under all types of light.
And then he finally decides to go out at night and use infrared video cameras.
And suddenly, he discovers this whole other side of these tree frogs.
And what happens is they're very territorial.
So, one tree frog is on a bush, and it really wants its bush to be its bush.
Right.
I'm not sharing this branch with anybody.
No, exactly.
Right.
